IDEA (http://www.intellij.com) has a source tree view that is perfect
for this situation.  With tests in the same package but in different
project subtrees, the view looks like this:

- ... \src\main
   - com
      - <company>
         + <pkg1>
         + <pkg2>

- ... \src\test
   - com
      - <company>
         + <pkg1>
         + <pkg2>

With all that I've heard about Eclipse, I'm surprised this type of view
is not present.  I would highly recommend IDEA if you choose to explore
other IDEs.  By the way, I rely on Ant to exclude test classes from the
main jar file; works nicely.

Regards,
Craig

> > Why don't you like keeping your tests in the same package scope,
> > but (optionally) in a physically separate directory ?

> One reason that I don't like it too much is that I cannot see the
> application code and the test code side by side in my package browser
- at
> least not in Eclipse. That's why I prefer to have both classes and
test
> classes in the same source tree as long as the code is in a constantly
> changing state. I move the test classes out as soon as the code is in
> "almost stable" state. Of course, I'd prefer the browser to merge
several
> source paths into a single view.
> 
> Johannes
